glossentry.glossterm: ELEMENT/ATTRIBUTE NAME (just as in the ORLANDO XML documents, in allcaps)

div.p: This term belongs to BIOGRAPHY PRODUCTION . records the effects of specific people, texts, events, or places that formed or developed the writer's thinking or practice as an artist. Influences can pertain to her individual texts or her work as a whole. It contains at least a full sentence, and usually at least one tagged NAME or TITLE. It is modified by an attribute, INLFUENCETYPE, which has three values: literary, intellectual, or familial.

div.codeblock: <PINFLUENCESHER INFLUENCETYPE=”LITERARY”>Angela Carter's neo-Gothic or magic realist writing is indebted to <NAME>Isak Dinesen</NAME>, <NAME>Djuna Barnes</NAME>, and <NAME>Jane Bowles</NAME>.</PINFLUENCESHER>
<PINFLUENCESHER INFLUENCETYPE=”LITERARY”>Carolina Nairne was greatly influenced by <name>Robert Burns</>.</PINFLUENCESHER>

<PINFLUENCESHER INFLUENCETYPE=”INTELLECTUAL”>Maud Sulter's poetry was influenced by her trip to the west coast of <PLACE><AREA>Africa</AREA>, in particular <REGION>St James Island</REGION><GEOG CURRENT=”Gambia”</GEOG></PLACE>, which was used as a shipping post for thousands of slaves in the nineteenth century.</PINFLUENCESHER>

div.p: This element differs from literary schools in that schools are known, named groups or organizations that merit discussion in and of themselves. This element does not include subscription or patronage, and direct imitation of another author is dealt with through TINTERTEXTUALITY.

Question: My author published her book by amassing subscribers. Are these people considered influences?Answer:Some of them might be influences and merit a mention in PINFLUENCESHER. But publishing by subscription is dealt with by use of element PMODEOFPUBLICATION with attribute SUBSCRIPTION.
Question: If the author was heavily influenced by her time in Paris, should I tag it here?
Answer:Yes, and use the place tag as needed.
